title: Emre Can 'keen on Manchester United move' as agent makes contact with clubs for ex-Liverpool man
text:
Juventus midfielder Emre Can is reportedly keen on a move to Manchester United and what would be a return to the Premier League.

The former Liverpool midfielder moved from Anfield to Juventus on a free transfer in the summer of 2018, but is particularly frustrated at a lack of minutes on the pitch so far this season - he has played just 78 minutes of club football.

These have come in just three substitute appearances for Maurizio Sarri's side, and therefore Can could move back to England after his agent made contact with various clubs, according to Italian outlet Tuttosport.

Emre Can is struggling for game-time under Juventus under new manager Maurizio Sarri

Former Juventus manager Massimiliano Allegri is being linked with the Manchester United job

Can could be a natural replacement for United midfielder Paul Pogba, who is constantly being linked with a move to Spain or a return to Juventus.

It has also been reported by the Italian paper that former Juventus manager Massimiliano Allegri is closing in on the hot seat at Manchester United, and wants to bring Can and Mario Mandzukic, the Croatian striker, with him as he plans an overhaul at Old Trafford.

Despite an impressive first season where he made 29 Serie A appearances as he helped the Old Lady to their eighth consecutive title, 25-year-old Can does not seemingly figure heavily in new manager Maurizio Sarri's plans this season.

Emre Can will return to Juventus after representing Germany in the international break

Can has played just 78 minutes of football so far this season in Serie A, and incredibly wasn't named in Juve's Champions League squad for the group stage of the competition.

Despite that, the midfielder was named in the recent Germany squad, but did receive a straight red card against Estonia in a Euro 2020 qualifier.

Juventus return to action against Bologna on Saturday and are currently top of Serie A by one points to Inter Milan.
